ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Suicide is common within communities and it is not limited to individuals/groups or race. What can you share with us about suicide in your community?
What has been your experience of dealing with suicidal behavior/suicide?
How has suicide been prevented in your community/district? What are you currently doing to prevent suicide?
What would you recommend as the best practices for suicide prevention in your community/district? What could be done to prevent suicide in your community/district?
Who is responsible for the prevention of suicide in the community/district?
What is your view concerning the strategy of using the District Health Management Teams (DHMT) as champions for suicide prevention in a district? Explain what DHMT is
What leadership support is available towards suicide prevention in your community/district?
Has there been any program (project) for suicide prevention in your community/district? If yes, describe it.
How can new ways of suicide prevention be embedded/integrated into the existing structures, policies and processes?
Which organizations and stakeholders should be involved in suicide prevention?
What are your perceptions about those who attempt or die by suicide?
How is suicide /suicidal behavior being reported to various stakeholders including the general public? How satisfied are you with the current reporting of suicide?
How common is suicide in your community (probe for numbers of suicide and suicide attempts, suicide planning)?
What are the common means for suicide in your community/district? How accessible and available are the means of suicide (e.g. pesticides, guns, ropes, jumping points) in your community/district?
What drives people in your community to attempt or commit suicide? Probe for socioeconomic and other issues
What are the most common social stressors for suicide in your community? (e.g. land wrangles, school/university students' examinations)

What is your view concerning psychosocial support/counselling (e.g. in the community such as those vulnerable and/or bereaved by suicide at schools/social centers) and suicide or attempted suicide? Is it available?
What is your view concerning health and welfare services available for individuals at risk of suicide?
What are the potential data sources on suicide (e.g., police statistics, records of health facilities, VHTs, DHIS2, etc.)?
What are the age groups affected by suicide (e.g., older persons, young, middle-aged)?
What is the contribution of alcohol or substance abuse to the suicide problem in your community/district?
Any additional information you would like to add concerning suicide prevention?
